results.title: Jedda
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel and Charles Chauvel Productions
results.brief_description:
As Australia’s first feature film with Aboriginal lead roles, Jedda is beloved by many First Peoples. It was one of the first times we saw stories of our people explored and it’s lauded for its representation of “so many Aboriginal men and women, girls and boys on the screen.” But despite being a first for First Peoples representation, Jedda also reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history characterised by formal policies of assimilation and the forced removal of Indigenous children from their families by the government.
The tale of an Aboriginal woman torn between her white upbringing and her heritage, Jedda (Charles Chauvel’s last feature film) is the first Australian-made colour feature and first Australian film nominated for the Cannes Film Festival’s Palme d’Or. It stars Arrernte actress Rosalie Kunoth-Monks (credited as Ngarla Kunoth) as Jedda and Tiwi actor Robert Tudawali as Marbuck. Due to the film’s popularity, and a rising interest in Aboriginal ‘kitsch’ and culture, Kunoth-Monks and Jedda became entwined. But unlike Tudawali, who had other roles, Kunoth-Monks never acted again and became an advocate for Australia’s First Peoples. Cast also includes Betty Suttor, Paul Reynall, George Simpson-Lytle, Tas Fitzer, Wason Byers, Willie Farrar, and Margaret Dingle

results.title: Peppimenarti
results.creator_credit: Ron Iddon, Film Australia and Leopardwood
results.brief_description: Peppimenarti is a cattle station in the Northern Territory near the Daly River, owned by First Nations people. Beginning by rounding up descendants of cattle who had strayed from other stations, the station has turned to a successful business enterprise with $1m turnover p.a. First Nations law takes precedence over European law, and all able-bodied men on the station must work, with none allowed to go on the dole. Peppimenarti stands as a shining example of the Outstation Movement, and has successfully combined western business sense with local customs.

results.title: Maydina the shadow 1890's
results.creator_credit: David Stevens, Bob Weis, Channel 0\28 and Generation Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Women of the sun (A)”.
Part Two of a series which presents events that occurred to four different aboriginal women at different periods in time. This episode examines the life of Maydina and her daughter on a church mission run by a self-appointed guardian at the turn of the century. Follows her struggle to return to a tribal existence and her efforts to prevent her daughter being taken away from her by the mission guardian.

results.title: The Legend of Jimmy Governor
results.brief_description:
Episode of ABC TV series ‘A Big Country’ exploring the real life story of Jimmy Governor, as compared to his fictional counterpart, Jimmie Blacksmith, in the novel and film, ‘The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith’. Includes interviews with author, Thomas Keneally, and film director, Fred Schepisi, on location during the making of the film.
Broadcast on ABC TV in April 1978. Reporter: Kenyon Castle. Narrator: Bob Plasto.

results.title: I, the Aboriginal
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes, Kip Porteous and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Set in and around Darwin the film discloses the life of an Australian First Nations man as depicted in Douglas Lockwood’s book of the same name. Philip Roberts recalls his early years of tribal life and gradual acceptance by the white community. He receives medical training, and travels frequently to his own people making use of his knowledge.

results.title: The Black man and his bride
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: By using camera movement and editing technique the film animates the series of paintings “The Black Man and his Bride”, by Arthur Boyd. Tim Burstall also wrote the original ballad sung to guitar accompaniment which runs for the duration of the film sung by Donald Ayrton.

results.title: My colour, your kind
results.brief_description: A young girl, incarcerated in a dormitory, escapes to her rightful place in the world. During the journey she recollects her life and the treatment she has endured. In My Colour, Your Kind director Danielle Mclean uses her experience as a fair skinned First Nations person to explore the notion of First Nations identity.

results.title: A Postcard from Ovens
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Jack Keane and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: An edited excerpt from ‘Working Holiday’ (1957) produced by Jack Keane for the Victorian Department of Agriculture. Shows hop picking in Victoria where seasonal workers gather from all parts of Australia for six weeks to harvest hops in the rich Ovens Valley. The weekend breaks are spent swimming, fishing or sight-seeing in the surrounding Alps.

results.title: Op shops of our town
results.brief_description: An amusing ‘mockumentary’ on several of the Op Shops in the East Gippsland region. This tongue-in-cheek journey introduces us to the eccentricities of op-shopping, the people who run them, the people who shop in them, and the eclectic mix of goods found in them. Stars Mr Kearney and Ms Jennian, with thanks to the following participating Op Shops - Paynesville Op Shop and Uniting Church, Lakes Entrance Ambulance, Salvos and St Vincents in Bairnsdale. Music from the fabulous Stereophonic Optigan, written and played by Mr Kearney. Camera - Jeremy Johnson.

results.title: Old man: returning to Lake Condah Mission

video_links.name: Old man: returning to Lake Condah Mission

results.brief_description: This is a documentary film about growing up on Lake Condah Aboriginal Mission. A local Elder, Uncle Kenny Saunders, visits the site of Lake Condah Mission and talks about his childhood memories revealing a past of cruelty and fear, and the devastation felt in the aftermath of the Eumerella massacres.
